Description: Body fragment of pottery closed vase, with root of handle, probably a hydria; exterior: steaky dull black with added white pendant lotue flower; below, white and red bands.
Curator's comments: Probably from same vase as British Museum 1888,0601.678.a, b+c and e; compare also 1965,0930.494. Gardner 1888, 47, makes special note of the find of 'very few' examples, all in very bad condition, of this 'peculiar' class of pottery (i.e. with painted decoration in white on a black glaze) in the Aphrodite sanctuary. He notes the occurrence of both animal and plant designs. Clay analysis with NAA by Hans Mommsen of this piece (sample Nauk 88) remains difficult to interpret; a possible Attic provenance (Mommsen et al. 2012, 440) can probably be discounted in favour of East Greek, notably Chian production, with the chemical composition of the fabric close to Chian pottery (close to chemical group ChiA, cf. Kerschner and Mommsen 2009, 134). Mommsen, H., Schlotzhauer, U., Villing, A. and Weber, S. 2012, ‘Herkunftsbestimmung von archaischen Scherben aus Naukratis und Tell Defenneh durch Neutronenaktivierungsanalyse’, in Schlotzhauer and Weber 2012, 433–55. Kerschner, M. and Mommsen, H., ‘Imports of East Greek pottery to Sicily and Sicilian productions of East Greek type. Archaeomoetric analyses of finds from the votive deposit in Katane’, in A. Pautasso 2009, Stipe votiva del santuario di Demetra a Catania. La Ceramica greco-orientale, Studi e materiali di archeologia greca 9, Catania, 125–50
It is possible that the palmettes here and on 1888,0601.678b+c are set between the handle roots.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GO.422)
